DOC.HEAD: Reagan and Judge in Poindexter Case at Odds
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan and the judge in John Poindexter's Iran-Contra case appear to be on a collision course over the use of the ex-president's notes and diaries in court. U.S. District Judge Harold Greene on Thursday gave Reagan until Jan. 7 to turn over to the court excerpts from those documents for possible use at Poindexter's trial. Greene said he wants to review material from the ex-president before deciding whether it should be supplied to Poindexter, who subpoenaed documents Reagan may have relating to 67 meetings and events. Fifty of them concern assistance to the Contras and 17 relate to the administration's secret arms sales to Iran. Greene said he is moving the start of the trial back a month to Feb. 20 to deal with the subpoena and other issues. The former national security adviser says Reagan's documents will bear out that the former president authorized activities for which Poindexter now is charged with crimes. ``The Court will ... promptly conduct its ... review of the Reagan documents ... and it will render a decision on the segments of the subpoena that will be quashed and the parts of the Reagan diary, notes and notebooks that must be made available'' for Poindexter's defense, said the judge. Lawyers for Reagan and the Justice Department had offered to let Greene see excerpts from the diary, but only if the former president and the Bush administration were permitted to see a proffer Poindexter filed spelling out why he believes he needs the Reagan material. The judge flatly refused to let them see the proffer now. ``It would be going too far to accord to the attorneys for President Reagan and for the incumbent president ... a special role in the determination whether particular documents'' must be turned over, said Greene. The judge noted their ``direct interest in the outcome'' of the subpoena dispute and said transferring the court's responsibilities to them would be ``unprecedented.'' Greene said the Justice Department and Reagan will be permitted to see the proffer next month, if the judge decides to turn the material over to Poindexter and Reagan invokes executive privilege. Using executive privilege, presidents can shield from public disclosure documents used in carrying out their constitutional duties. Poindexter is accused of conspiracy, two counts of obstructing Congress and two counts of making false statements. The charges focus on his alleged lies about a November 1985 CIA-assisted shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran and denials that North was raising money and providing military advice to the Contras. Meanwhile, Iran-Contra prosecutors say Greene's restrictions on Oliver L. North's testimony may make it impossible to use the former White House aide as a witness against Poindexter. Greene said he would limit North's testimony because it might have been tainted by Poindexter's immunized testimony on Capitol Hill in 1987. The judge's decision rules out use of most of North's testimony from his trial in April, in which North frequently mentioned his former boss. But the office of the independent counsel Lawrence Walsh urged Greene to ``permit North to testify to all events he currently recalls ... even if his current recollection has been refreshed by Poindexter's immunized testimony.'' Refreshing his recollection from Poindexter's congressional appearance ``does not constitute an impermissible use of that immunized testimony,'' said prosecutors. North said last week he doesn't want to testify against Poindexter. North's ``demonstrated unwillingness to answer substantively any question posed to him by the government ... may well preclude ... from calling this witness at all,'' Walsh's office said in court papers.
